tool.name: OSMGPNodeLoader

param.name: in_osmNodeFile
param.dialogReference: OpenStreetMap file containg the node elements to load in XML format.
param.pythonReference: OpenStreetMap file containg the node elements to load in XML format.

param.name: in_fieldNames
param.displayname: Node tag keys to load for point features
param.dialogReference: The name of tag keys to be loaded as attributes for point features. If no names are given the tool uses a default set of ('name', 'highway', 'building', 'natural', 'waterway', 'amenity', 'landuse', 'place', 'railway', 'boundary','power','leisure','man_made', 'shop', 'tourism', 'route', 'barrier', 'surface', 'type', 'service', 'sport').
param.pythonReference: The name of tag keys to be loaded as attributes for point features. If no names are given the tool uses a default set of ('name', 'highway', 'building', 'natural', 'waterway', 'amenity', 'landuse', 'place', 'railway', 'boundary','power','leisure','man_made', 'shop', 'tourism', 'route', 'barrier', 'surface', 'type', 'service', 'sport').

param.name: in_useFeatureCache
param.dialogReference:
Use this option for a recycling cursor to insert features into the geodatabase.

  • DO_NOT_USE_CACHE Do not use a recycling cursor to insert nodes into the geodatabase. All fields are written for each feature. This is the default.

  • USE_CACHE Use a recycling cursor to insert nodes into the geodatabase. Only the osmTags and osmSupportingElement fields is written for each feature and the other field attributes as needed, meaning that not all field values are reset for each feature, only the values that are needed for the current feature. This can lead to attribute values that are 'shared' across features. This might be incorrect but the data loading is faster. Only features where the osmSupportingElement value is 'no' will have the correct attributes.
param.pythonReference:
Use this option for a recycling cursor to insert features into the geodatabase.

  • DO_NOT_USE_CACHE Do not use a recycling cursor to insert nodes into the geodatabase. All fields are written for each feature. This is the default.

  • USE_CACHE Use a recycling cursor to insert nodes into the geodatabase. Only the osmTags and osmSupportingElement fields is written for each feature and the other field attributes as needed, meaning that not all field values are reset for each feature, only the values that are needed for the current feature. This can lead to attribute values that are 'shared' across features. This might be incorrect but the data loading is faster. Only features where the osmSupportingElement value is 'no' will have the correct attributes.

param.name: out_osmNodePoints
param.dialogReference: Name of the output point feature class. This feature class contains the OpenStreetMap node elements.
param.pythonReference: Name of the output point feature class. This feature class contains the OpenStreetMap node elements.

tool.summary: This tool loads nodes from a OpenStreetMap XML file into a geodatabase and creates point features from the content.
tool.usage:
• The tool is used in combination with the OSM File Loadertool.

  • The tool only processes the node elements from the OpenStreetMap source file.

  • Streamline the loading of tags into attributes. If no tags are provided, a set of default tags is used. The default set consists of ('name', 'highway', 'building', 'natural', 'waterway', 'amenity', 'landuse', 'place', 'railway', 'boundary','power','leisure','man_made', 'shop', 'tourism', 'route', 'barrier', 'surface', 'type', 'service', 'sport').

scriptExample.title: Loading node element with default attribute set
scriptExample.para: Load the node elements from the OpenStreetMap XML file into a point feature class.
scriptExample.code:
# load the arcpy module import arcpy
# load the OpenStreetMap toolbox arcpy.ImportToolbox(r'C:\Program Files (x86)\ArcGIS\Desktop10.3\ArcToolbox\Toolboxes\OpenStreetMap Toolbox.tbx')
# target point feature class point_fc = r'D:\OSM\country.gdb\liechtenstein_pt'
# OpenStreetMap XML file osm_source = r'D:\OSM\liechtenstein-nodes.osm'
# load the node elements into points for Liechtenstein arcpy.OSMGPNodeLoader_osmtools(osm_source, '#', 'DO_NOT_USE_CACHE', point_fc)

dataIdInfo.idAbs: This tool loads nodes from a OpenStreetMap XML file into a geodatabase and creates point features from the content.
